Q4dArTu7.question: Give the meaning of the acronym PUDSOD.

options.text: Pitot underreads in descent, static overreads in descent
Pilot-used device – system-operated device
Performance unit drive system on drive
Previously used DME source of distance measurement

ESK5nnnF.question: The factor(s) which are considered by the FMS for Cost Index (CI) is/are:

options.text: One engine inoperative.
One engine inoperative and flaps stuck partially deployed.
Landing gear stuck down.
Air brakes stuck partially deployed.

kzEVzX02.question: Waypoints can be entered in an INS memory in different formats. In which of the following formats can waypoints be entered into all INSs?

options.text: Geographic coordinates.
By waypoints name.
Hexadecimal.
Bearing and distance.

oIHuPj2y.question:
The FMS navigation data base usually contains 
1 airport reference data
2 ATC frequencies
3 Company routes.
4 NavAid frequencies
	The combination regrouping all the correct statements is

options.text: 1 and 3.

X3LDXnX0.question: The purpose of an FCU/MCP is to...

options.text: operate automation modes.
verify thrust mode selections.
verify engaged modes of operation.
operate the FMC.

YEjniSgC.question: A flight control system is fail-operational if, in the event of a failure

options.text: the approach, flare and landing can be completed automatically.
the approach only can be completed automatically.
there is no significant out-of-trim condition or deviation of flight path or attitude but the landing is not completed automatically.
the landing is not completed automatically.

Ck5LXC0V.question: What does the FMS compute during normal LNAV mode?

options.text: The great circle track between two or more waypoints, based on IRS, VOR, DME and GNSS information.
The optimum vertical flight profile, taking into account efficient fuel consumption based on the cost index.
The altitude restrictions of the airspace above, and the minimum crossing altitude of a waypoint.
The lateral flight path with regard to the theoretical performance of the aircraft from the performance database.

6izDxVUy.question: When engaged in the FMS lateral navigation mode (NAV or LNAV) the autopilot uses the command provided by the

options.text: FMS
track selector.
VOR or Localizer receiver.
VOR receiver.

qm0TXqFP.question: When the autopilot is coupled to the normal LNAV mode, the FMS computes...

options.text: the great circle track between the waypoints, by using VOR, DME, GNSS and IRS input.
the optimum vertical flight path, based on fuel consumption and cost index.
altitude restrictions of the airspaces and altitude requirements for crossing waypoints.
the lateral flight path, based on the aircraft's performance database.

eMa3beKW.question: During the final approach, ILS and FD show contradicting information. The pilot flying should...

options.text: follow the ILS and ignore the FD.
follow the PAPI.
declare an emergency.
follow the FD and ignore the ILS.

IoscRq3F.question: What should the pilot do in case of information mismatch between the ILS and FD on final approach?

options.text: Follow the ILS and ignore FD.
Follow the FD and ignore ILS.
Continue normally.
Follow the PAPIS.

b36QOEeL.question: The purpose of the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is to:

options.text: check and confirm any selection made by the pilot on the autopilot control panel
check and confirm in which mode the FMS is operating.
visualise the instantaneous flight path of the aeroplane.
visualise any input made by the pilot on the control commands.

qsGu954k.question: The purpose of the Flight Mode Annunciator (FMA) is to:

options.text: Check and confirm in which modes the automatic flight control systems are armed and/or engaged.
Visually announce any EGPWS alarm.
Visually announce any ACAS alarm.
Check and confirm the aeroplane configuration.

LIaJLKbj.question: When engaged in the FMS lateral navigation mode (LNAV) the autopilot uses:

options.text: the roll or heading command computed by the FMS.
the FMS active (TO) waypoint coordinates.
the path angle command computed by the FMS.
the FMS computation of the aircraft position and the FMS active (TO) waypoint bearing.

LwgKvj3C.question: Regarding automatic flight control, which equipment is required for the FMS to control the vertical flight path?

options.text: Auto throttle
Pitch controller
Flight director
Electronic flight bag

S5t4d390.question: On a modern commercial aircraft, the FMS provides:

options.text: lateral and vertical navigation, and guidance and performance management.
traffic alert information
an air ground/data link.
a 3D area navigation and an air/ground datalink.

OznFJ7bC.question: When selecting navaids to auto-tune in order to update position, the FMS selects:

options.text: The optimum navaids in terms of signal strength and geometry.
The closest navaids.
Only those navaids in the active flight plan.
The optimum navaids along track and back-course.

BfxmYLjn.question: The Flight Management System (FMS) is organised in such a way that the pilot can:

options.text: insert additional temporary navigation data between two database updates.
modify the data in the navigation database between two updates.
read and write at any time in any database.
modify any of the databases every 28 days.

qkddPs9g.question: The flight crew just filled out the pre-flight FMS data with their route info. They realize afterward that the Navigation Database is out of date. What will happen if they decide to update the database to the current cycle?

options.text: The data they entered will be deleted.
The inserted route info will still be there.
Some of the route legs will be missing.
The FMS restarts and all previous info will be deleted.

V3icR1AQ.question:
An aircraft with a dual FMS configuration is ready to descend, according to the profile of an instrument approach procedure. An amber message is generated on the Crew Alerting System (CAS) concerning the failure of No.1 (Flight Management Computer FMC1). Following the failure of FMC1, which of the following are correct?
1. Both FMS units operate in independent mode (degraded operation), 
 2. FMS2 operates in single mode, while FMS1 has failed, 
 3. FMS2 computations are unreliable due to faulty data sent from FMS1, 
 4. The crew shall revert to other navigational sources, if required.

options.text: 2 and 4
1 and 4
3 and 4
2 and 3

gFtZRhJE.question: In order for the FMS to function properly, it is compulsory for certain data to be entered. How is the compulsory data identified on the display of the CDU/MCDU? By using:

options.text: Rectangular boxes.
Shaded white characters.
Magenta characters.
Dashed lines.

14GskXhU.question: Which Flight Management System databases are typically loadable?

options.text: The navigation database and the performance database.
The navigation database and the operating system.
The navigation database and the user database.
The performance database and the user database.

auiaAQPv.question:
The role of the FMS is to aid the flight crew with:

1 – immediate actions in case of emergency procedure2 – navigation3 – in-flight performance optimisation4 – electronic check-lists.
The combination that regroups all of the correct statements is:

JzUggKm5.question: After an approach at your destination, the weather is found to be below limits, and you decide to divert to your alternate aerodrome. During initial climb you notice that the leading-edge devices are not completely retracted. After completing all necessary actions to deal with this abnormal condition, you check the FMS for ETA and fuel remaining at the diversion aerodrome. Based on the above, you can...

options.text: use the FMS time predictions, but you can NOT use the fuel predictions.
use both the FMS time and fuel predictions.
NOT use the FMS time predictions, but you can use the FMS fuel predictions.
NOT use any of the FMS time or fuel predictions.

HG9IWciU.question: In the B737-400 Flight Management System the CDUs are used during preflight to:

options.text: manually initialize the IRSs and FMC with dispatch information.
manually initialize the Flight Director System and FMC with dispatch information.
automatically initialize the IRSs and FMC with dispatch information.
manually initialize the IRSs, FMC and autothrottle with dispatch information.

wYwxHhLD.question: When is the FMS aircraft database updated?

options.text: After an FMS software update
Monthly
Manually by the pilot
Weekly

U8AfFFmT.question: In a Flight Management System (FMS), control Display Units (CDUs) are used preflight to

options.text: Manually initialize the IRSs and FMC with dispatch information
Manually initialize the IRSs, FMC and Autothrottle with dispatch information
Manually initialize the Flight Director System and FMC with dispatch information
Automatically initialize the IRSs and FMC with dispatch information

WcPp1A59.question: RNP1 (Required Navigation Performance) requires a navigation performance of plus or minus...

options.text: 1 NM both lateral and longitudinal 95% of the flying time
1 NM lateral 95% and longitudinal 90% of the flying time
2 NM lateral 95% and longitudinal 90% of the flying time
1 NM lateral 90% and longitudinal 95% of the flying time
Performance and navigation database
TCAS and GPWS
GPS and GLONASS
Autoflight systems and EFIS

mXADfcUx.question: During the cockpit preparation phase, the flight crew notices that the Performance Database is incorrect on the FMS, being for a different aircraft and engine type. What must they do in this case?

options.text: The mechanics must change the database.

Nothing, this is not an issue.

IQzIoBsp.question: The performance factor is used to correct predicted fuel flow when the actual aircraft drag and the engine performance differs from the nominal model due to:

options.text: The FMS computer integrates performance management with Area Navigation.

1 – distance2 – altitude constraint or prediction3 – waypoint elevation4 – track

weekly.

Pitch Controller

options.text: In `Independent Mode` both FMCs are decoupled, and there is zero cross-checking between them.

In `Dual Mode` both FMCs independently process the pilots` inputs
there is zero cross-checking between the FMCs.

options.text: maximum range airspeed.

lI16ekX6.question:

none as it uses radio aids for position, not GPS

pGJNgw9w.question:

4PL0BKfS.question: The number included in the RNP Specification (e.g. RNP 5) describes the required:

options.text: Non precision approaches

Navigation Display.
Symbol Generator.

the distance error between the FMS computed position and the IRS computed position.
the distance error between the FMS computed position and the GPS computed position.
the angular distance error, to the left or right from the desired track (DT) to the aircraft track (TK).

options.text: He cannot. For the pilot the FMS data base is read-only.
When deemed necessary.
When there is a fault.

6fwE7yjK.question: During the cockpit preparation, the pilot has started to load the route into the FMS and, because of a distraction, he accidentally changed the current navigation database with a newer version before its active date. Is this an issue and why?

options.text: It can be an issue because certain waypoints and airways might have changed their coordinates, and the aircraft will follow an incorrect routing.
It is not a problem if the captain’s FMS still has the old (correct) database.
It is a problem and you will probably get a warning.
It is an issue because the pilot will need to load the flight plan again.

vAVoy5bl.question:

wZcTIFSD.question: For which non-standard configuration can an FMS normally compute the fuel prediction?

options.text: One engine inoperative.

Flaps/slats not retracted and gear down.

xydCgIn1.question: What will happen if the GPS position inputs to the FMS are reduced?

options.text: Position computation is less accurate and RNAV approaches are not available anymore.
The FMS will become inoperative but the RNAV approaches will still be available.

The FMS will become inoperative.

nZBL3nhN.question: The FMS navigation database processing should include the following check(s):

options.text: at each phase of the process, from the reception of each supplier's data to the distribution and loading of the formatted database.
at the loading phase into the FMS, the check is performed by the FMS.
at the end of the FMS formatting phase of all of the data collected and assembled.
at the reception of each supplier's data and after the assembly of those data collected.

dnD1QbE5.question: What is the core functionality of the FMS?

options.text: Construction of the flight plan and of the four-dimensional aircraft trajectory.
Flight plan construction and communication.
Construction of the flight plan and of the two-dimensional aircraft trajectory.
Construction of the two-dimensional aircraft trajectory for navigation purposes.

iQ4MpRJO.question: The FMS Overfly function consists in:

options.text: Manually selecting a flight plan waypoint to fly over when sequencing it instead of flying by at the transition.

hcsKQKBn.question: The FMS is approved for Localizer approaches:

a VOR receiver.

a DME receiver.

e8MIj6wu.question:
In a dual FMS architecture, when an incompatibility between the two FMC's occurs:

one FMC is automatically switched OFF.

rOD9ULzR.question: What should be done in case of failure of one FMC unit?

GV44vE5y.question: The FMS can automatically tune radio navigation facilities in its database. Its choice is based on the:

noz0fX4U.question: During start-up, the pilot notices the unserviceability of an item mentioned in the Minimum Equipment List (MEL). On the INIT page, the pilot...

options.text: can only confirm the current aircraft model and type.

5CyG3bPG.question: What is the purpose of a performance database?

To monitor the performance of the crew.

Vs7Vl7Qs.question: The duration of a FMS navigation database loaded before expiring is

options.text: 28 days.
3 months.
15 days.

R8tYbPse.question:

FMS will issue a warning.
FMS needs to be reinitialized to give correct calculations.
The discrepancy might go undetected.

Navigation database and EGPWS information.

Only before take-off.

0RPrmu7X.question: On a typical Navigation Display (ND) the current in-flight Wind Velocity (W/V) is displayed. Where is the W/V information derived from?

options.text: It is determined by the FMC from inputs of heading, drift, True Airspeed (TAS) and ground speed.
It is entered into the FMC by either the pilots or dispatch/operations.
It is manually entered by the pilots, based on the latest information available.

options.text: Wind information is calculated by the Flight Management Computer (FMC) from heading, drift, true air speed and ground speed.

It is manually entered by the pilots, based on the latest information available.
It is entered into the FMC by either the pilots or dispatch/operations.

h3OlZUUl.question: Which of the following statements regarding the "performance factor" is correct? It is a...

options.text: positive or negative factor that is used to correct the predicted fuel flow.
positive factor that is used to show the percentage increase in fuel consumption when there is an abnormal increase in drag.
positive or negative factor that is used to calculate the percentage error in fuel consumption due to differences between nominal and icing conditions.

only one FMC feeds the two FMS`s.
one FMC is used by the captain, the other by the first officer. The FMC`s are not synchronised.

a time addition that has to be applied to the ETAs overhead waypoints to account for changes in speed

a factor applied to the Take-Off Distance Required (TODR) under ISA conditions to get the TODR underr actual conditions

09bXzXQl.question: What is the validity period of the permanent data base of aeronautical information stored in the FMS is

YgeyJqCQ.question: The period of validity of an FMS database is:

varies depending on the area of operational cover.
one week.

h0jwBLBV.question: In a dual FMS architecture, what happens if one of the FMS fails?

TWKafLMQ.question:

1 and 3 only
1 and 2 only

9Mh5lUo5.question: The Fuel management performed by most FMS along the flight plan is considered as:

an accurate function which can be considered as the prime mean to determine the remaining fuel quantity along the flight plan.
the prime mean to manage the fuel consumption along the flight.
an accurate and very reliable function providing that the fuel on board quantity has been properly initialized by the crew before start up.

XYJ103Ep.question:

options.text: to navigation performance within an airspace.
to navigation performance within an airspace using satellite navigation systems only.
to navigation performance on RNAV routes only.
to navigation performance within an airspace and a specific time-interval.

is updated via datalink on a permanent basis to contain actual NOTAMs.
need to be updated by the cockpit crew as soon as the performance database is updated.

h36mSVno.question: During FMS initialization, the crew must verify that the aircraft performance database correct, based on the aeroplane and engine configuration. This is because the FMS uses the data to...

in dual mode no information is exchanged, the FMCs are not synchronised and each FMC outputs to only one pilot's peripherals
in independent mode information is exchanged and each FMC outputs to one pilot's CDU and EFIS displays

line selected.

Fly the aircraft

fGYdyzQB.question: How is the data inserted in the MCDU displayed?

CPQ07O5X.question: Concerning the FMS, entering a cost index of zero:

does not influence the FMS cruising speed.

kDgfFqZ1.question: In the Boeing 737-400 FMS, the CDU is used to:

automatically initialize the IRS and FMC with dispatch information.
manually initialize the Flight Director System and FMC with dispatch information.
manually initialize the Flight Director System, FMC and Autothrottle with dispatch information.

Es5RliFI.question: During a ground stop the Commander notices that the FMS position is NOT in agreement with the actual aircraft position. What is the correct procedure to rectify this error? The Commander needs to...

options.text: use the CDU to enter the correct position into the system.
contact maintenance personnel to recalibrate the system.
activate the GNSS to allow the position to be automatically corrected
note the difference and manually correct calculations for the rest of the flight.

6LxpMW5K.question: Which of the following lists the first three pages of the FMC/CDU normally used to enter data on initial start-up of the B737-400 Electronic Flight Instrument System?

IDENT - RTE - DEPARTURE.
POS INIT - RTE - DEPARTURE.
POS INIT - RTE - IDENT.

90TJE50A.question: For a FMS designed with the lateral navigation (LNAV) capability coupled to the autopilot, the FMS lateral command output is

a lateral acceleration.
a longitudinal acceleration and a roll rate.

AYYWAVpq.question: With regard to a dual Flight Management System (FMS), which statement is correct? (Note: FMC = Flight Management Computer)

options.text: Both FMC are decoupled in “independent mode”, and cross-checking between them does not occur.
Both FMC are decoupled in “single mode”, and every system provides its own independent information to the flight crew.

Both FMC are decoupled in “dual mode”, and cross-checking between them is very limited.

uvJdO8W1.question:
For most FMS the Fuel prediction function, which computes the remaining fuel along the flight plan, takes into account the following situations:

rejects initial longitude error, but it will accept latitude error.

DNG16hKE.question: Is it possible for the flight crew to change data in the performance database?

Yes, it can only change the fuel consumption.

54eqBb7d.question: What does the pilot need to do regarding the performance database in the FCM before taking off?

sf6ebVgo.question: Which statement about RNP is correct?

RNP requires a navigation performance accuracy lateral, longitudinal, vertical and timing for 95% of the flying time.

VPyNk7fb.question: Which statement about ADFs is correct?

options.text: ADFs can receive and take bearings on any broadcasting station transmitting within the frequency band 190 - 1750 kHz.
ADFs can receive any broadcasting station transmitting within the frequency band 190 - 1750 kHz but cannot take bearings on them.
ADFs cannot receive broadcasting stations transmitting within the frequency band 190 - 1750 kHz because NDBs are either N0N/A1A or A2A modulated and not A3E modulated like broadcasting stations.
ADFs cannot receive broadcasting stations transmitting within the frequency band 190 - 1750 kHz because NDBs are amplitude modulated and not frequency modulated like broadcasting stations.

FV9d1myz.question: Which statement about ADFs is correct?

options.text: ADFs can receive and take bearings on any broadcasting station transmitting within the frequency band 190 – 1750 kHz.
ADFs can receive any broadcasting station transmitting within the frequency band 190 – 1750 kHz but cannot take bearings on them.
ADFs cannot receive broadcasting stations transmitting within the frequency band 190 – 1750 kHz because NDBs are amplitude modulated and not frequency modulated like broadcasting stations.
ADFs cannot receive broadcasting stations transmitting within the frequency band 190 – 1750 kHz because NDBs are either N0N/A1A or A2A modulated and not A3E modulated like broadcasting stations.

axL5Q0Xx.question: Which statement about EGNOS is correct?

EGNOS is a local area augmentation system operation in North America.

With EGNOS installed in an aircraft, the GNSS-receiver can use satellites from all Global Navigation Satellite Systems in order to get better accuracy.

can still use the FMS to fly the RNAV approach, RAIM is only applicable to GPS approaches.
can still use the FMS to fly the RNAV approach, RAIM is only applicable to GPS approaches and ground track and speed information is NOT needed for an RNAV approach.

hViz7xTM.question: During initialisation of the FMS, the pilot selects the current database. He/she enters the route and waypoints for the flight. options.text: A problem as it will erase the current route and waypoints already put in.
NOT a problem. The FMS will automatically switch to the current database.
NOT possible as there only is one navigation database available for selection.
NOT a problem. The route and waypoints remain active.

acwBjqyQ.question: For which unusual aircraft configuration can the FMC calculate the fuel requirements?

options.text: One engine inoperative
Speed brakes stuck and one engine inoperative
Landing gear down, and slats/flaps not retracted
Slats/flaps not retracted

tzrAlNkp.question: A cost index of zero on an FMS is:

options.text: Maximum range
Minimum range
Minimum time
Maximum time

options.text: high airspeed and high fuel consumption.
maximum range airspeed.
minimum airspeed.
minimum trip fuel.

RejgecjI.question: The data stored in the performance database of an FMS is mainly used..

options.text: to calculate engine thrust settings.
to calculate IRS positions.
for LNAV calculations

Gz3gK3ja.question: What is meant by the “Performance factor”?

The take-off performance (take-off distance required, TODR) under the actual weather and airfield conditions, relative to standard conditions.

WpRo10Fu.question: In a typical FMS architecture including two FMCs, two CDUs and one cross-talk bus when the system operates in the normal DUAL mode, one (1) _____ is the master and the other is the slave. Both (2) _____ exchange data together and synchronise via a cross-talk bus.

tuning occurs much quicker than with manual selection.

uw1CppYj.question: What is the main threat arising after the flight crew accidentally changes the active navigation database with the standby database?

uq4Cf3Sl.question: Which statement is true for aircraft equipment which operates to RNP 1 and better?

EFmJT916.question: What is the purpose of the FMS performance database?

9yV8td1G.question:

e5pSER1Y.question: Which one of the following is an advantages of a multi-sensor system using inputs from a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) and an inertial reference system (IRS)?

The only advantage of coupling both systems is double redundancy

pXX7L9Zl.question: Which one of the following is an advantages of a multi-sensor system using inputs from a global navigation satellite system (GNSS) and an inertial reference system (IRS)?

The GNSS is never used as an input in a multi-sensor system.

slNolRLV.question: Which of the following are typical inputs to a Flight Management System (FMS)?

JLxOGY5R.question: Which statement is true about the navigational database of a FMS?

options.text: Crew created navigational data may be saved in additional space in the database.

Crew-inserted navigational data is deleted automatically after each flight.

Rb7A0WzT.question: Which statement is true about the navigational database of a FMS?

options.text: The navigational database is read-only, but space exists for crew-created navigational data.

The navigational database is write-protected and it is not possible to otherwise save crew created navigational data.

aEe76Cyw.question: An aircraft not equipped with EFIS has an inflight master caution. How can the pilots know what the failure is?

options.text: The pilots should check the annunciator panel of the flight warning system.
The pilots should refer to the emergency checklist.
The pilots should refer to the quick reference handbook.
It is type specific, so the pilots should check the FCOM abnormal procedures.

HnXVQm4g.question: A pilot conducting a single-pilot operation flight is doing some paperwork/administrative tasks and he is not looking at the cockpit instruments panel. How will he be informed if an immediate crew awareness but no immediate action is required?

options.text: Amber or yellow warning and aural warning.
Aural warning only.
An indication.
Red visual warning only.
provides a mode-selectable flight progress display.
provides all the parameters required for flight path control.
is an electronic instrument showing published navigation charts.
is a full-colour aircraft systems navigation display.

s3NckkA2.question: Which one of the following would be a likely purpose for user-defined waypoints based on latitude/longitude coordinates?

options.text: Planning routes that are far from fixed waypoints or navigation aids.
Planning routes that cross the borders between two or more different States.
Inserting, into the navigation system, new radio navigation aids for which the information in the AIP still needs to be updated.
Marking points of interest that lie close to the planned flight in order to inform the passengers on board.

ra65VOPH.question: The flight data recorder must automatically stop data recording when the:

options.text: Airplane cannot any longer move by its own power.
Landing gear is extended and locked.
Airplane clears the runway.
Main gear shock strut compresses when touching  the runway.

options.text: Aeroplane cannot any longer move by its own power.
Main gear shock strut compresses when touching  the runway.
Aeroplane clears the runway.
Landing gear is extended and locked.

9jIlQHfc.question: Cockpit voice recordings may not be used for any other purpose other than accident or incident investigation:

options.text: Without the consent of all crewmembers
Without the consent of the aircraft Captain
Except for maintenance analysis
Without the consent of the next of kin of all deceased crew

O95NT9YV.question: When must the flight data recorder automatically stop data recording?

options.text: When the aeroplane cannot any longer move by its own power.
When the main gear shock strut compresses when touching the runway.
When the aeroplane clears the runway.
When the landing gear is extended and locked.

fbQVQ0Bm.question: What technologies are used for data storage in aircraft recording systems?

options.text: Chip circuits and magnetic tape.
Chip circuits and capacitors.
Scratch foil and capacitors.
Electric wire and optical discs.
